title: Campaign Wire: A Guide to the 2018 Midterm Elections
content:
HOUSTON — PRESIDENT TRUMP REFLECTED on his evolving relationship with Sen. Ted Cruz at a rally in Texas on Monday , describing his onetime political rival as “ a really good friend of mine . ”
At a rally in Houston , Mr. Trump told voters to re-elect Mr. Cruz next month , saying that the fragile majority Republicans currently hold in the Senate is challenging his efforts to get important legislation through , including his proposed border wall .
“ Together , with a lot of other great Republicans , we are defending your freedom , ” he told the boisterous crowd . The event was shifted to a larger arena to accommodate interest , according to Mr. Trump ’ s campaign .
`` It 's true what they say , '' he said as he took the stage . `` Everything in Texas is just bigger . ''
Mr. Trump was stumping for a candidate who polling shows has a comfortable lead some two weeks before the election . Mr. Cruz faces Democratic Rep. Beto O ’ Rourke . Two polls released in mid-October showed Mr. Cruz ahead of Mr. O ’ Rourke by 9 percentage points .
The Trump campaign said that 100,000 people had expressed interest in the free tickets for the event . The Toyota Arena , which holds 18,000 , was crowded but not at capacity during the rally .
A number of people interviewed by The Wall Street Journal said while they would likely vote for Mr. Cruz in the midterm election next month , it was Mr. Trump they had gone to see .
`` I do like Ted Cruz a lot but I 'm here to see Donald Trump , '' Rick LaBlanc , a retired oil industry executive , said . `` I 'm a Trump man . ''
NO DEMOCRAT HAS WON A RACE STATEWIDE in Texas since 1994 . The Democratic Party has looked at Texas longingly for years , hoping that it might capitalize on shifting demographics in the big cities , while Republicans have counted on it as a solid block across the south and southwest .
`` Maybe in the future , but I do n't think right now , '' said Suzanne Asevedo , a greater Houston resident , of a Democrat 's chance of holding a statewide office in Texas . `` I think we 're still pretty conservative here . ''
`` Cruz and Trump are right for that . Beto , not so much , '' she said .
MR. O'ROURKE HAS ALREADY made a noteworthy impression on voters across the state . His campaign said this month that he raised $ 38.1 million in the three-month Federal Election Commission reporting period that ended Sept. 30 , the largest-ever quarterly haul for a Senate candidate .
Mr. Trump called Mr. O ’ Rourke `` a radical , open borders left-winger . ”
Texas Republican Gov . Greg Abbott joined in on the calls to vote for Mr. Cruz , telling supporters that “ Beto O ’ Rourke is hostile to Texas values '' and `` against good quality judges . ”
Mr. O'Rourke told a national television audience Thursday that he 'd vote to impeach Mr. Trump and believes Texas can lead the way to a national embracing of relaxed immigration policies and gun control .
Mr. Cruz called his opponent a “ gun-grabbing liberal , ” vowing to fight for Second Amendment protections if he is re-elected .
Mr. O ’ Rourke ’ s campaign didn ’ t respond to a request for comment .
Mr. Trump added that Mr. Cruz “ did a beautiful job in staring down an angry left wing mob in our recent Supreme Court battle - victory - whatever you want to call it . ”
Messrs. Trump and Cruz exchanged bitter insults during the 2016 presidential campaign , and Mr. Cruz took a while to come around and support the would-be president . Since Mr. Trump has taken office , however , Mr. Cruz has been an outspoken advocate for his efforts to crackdown on immigration , repeal the Affordable Care Act and nominate conservative judges to the Supreme Court .
`` We had our little difficulties , ” Mr. Trump said of his relationship with Mr. Cruz during Monday ’ s rally . “ But actually if you remember in the beginning it was a lovefest .... then it got nasty .
“ And then it ended and I ’ ll tell you what nobody has helped me more , ” he said .

Mr. Trump added that Mr. Cruz “did a beautiful job in staring down an angry left wing mob in our recent Supreme Court battle - victory - whatever you want to call it.”

Messrs. Trump and Cruz exchanged bitter insults during the 2016 presidential campaign, and Mr. Cruz took a while to come around and support the would-be president. Since Mr. Trump has taken office, however, Mr. Cruz has been an outspoken advocate for his efforts to crackdown on immigration, repeal the Affordable Care Act and nominate conservative judges to the Supreme Court.
